book.summary: A story about high school students and the mysterious Boogiepop legend.

chapter.title: Boogiepop
chapter.summary: Students discuss the Boogiepop legend, and one claims to see the mysterious figure on the school roof.

sequence.summary: Lunch conversation about the Boogiepop legend and rumors about Kirima Nagi.

beat.paragraph: The narrator introduces the Boogiepop rumor spreading among students. Recently, a strange rumor, or rather, a bit of a ghost story, has been spreading among the girls of the second year classes.

Description of Boogiepop's appearance and purpose. It's something about the mysterious Boogiepop. Boogiepop is short, wears a black cape, and has a tall hat that's sort of like the one Maetel wore in Galaxy Express 999, only narrower. He's an assassin, and he can kill people instantly, without pain. He always does so when you are at your most beautiful, before you start to wither away, before you grow old and ugly.
The connection between Boogiepop and missing girls. Nobody knows where he's from, but most people seem to agree that he has something to do with the string of missing high school girls in the area.

The narrator's thoughts on why people believe in such stories. Everyone wants to believe that the runaways were killed by an assassin that wanders in the shadows, fleeting like the morning mist, instead of running off to Tokyo or some other grim reality. Reality is always rather dreary. When people vanish from it, it's natural to want to connect them to some sort of fantasy, to some other world.

beat.summary: Conversation about The Village of Eight Graves.
beat.paragraph: Kyoko asks about The Village of Eight Graves. "Hey, Suema, what was the actual case that inspired The Village of Eight Graves?"
Suema answers immediately. "The Tsuyama Thirty," I said, without a second's thought.
Kyoko confirms the answer fits. "Hunh, Tsuyama Thirty—hey, it fits. Thanks."
Classmates express surprise at Suema's knowledge. "How did you know that?"
Classmate comments on Suema's interests. "You are obsessed."
Another classmate's reaction. "Don't be stupid, everyone knows that."
Classmates admit they don't know. "We don't! Nobody does!"
Suema explains how she knows. "There was a book on it out last month," I replied, in a knowing manner as if to brush them off.
Classmates react to Suema's explanation. "We didn't read it! Why would we?"
Classmate calls Suema scary. "You're a little scary, Kazuko."
Everyone laughs at Suema. Everyone cackled.
Kyoko asks about who might be a killer in their class. "What kind of person can murder someone?" Kyoko asked, suddenly looking up from her crossword again.
Suema's general response. "What kind? All kinds."
Kyoko clarifies her question. "I mean, like, who in this class seems likely to?" she said, lowering her voice.
Classmate urges Kyoko to continue. "Oooh, do tell, do tell!" Everyone leaned closer.

Kyoko describes someone who might be a killer. "Uhhh, someone a little stiff, like they're off in their own little world and are kinda stubborn when it comes to stuff?" Even as I said it, I knew I might as well be saying her name.
Classmate suggests Kirima Nagi. "So…Kirima Nagi?" Yep, first name out; the most notorious student in our class. She was skipping today, apparently; no sign of her all morning.
Classmate agrees Nagi isn't normal. "Hmm, well, she's not normal, that's for sure."
Classmate calls Nagi the Fire Witch. "Not normal? The Fire Witch is six kinds of crazy!"
Classmate mentions Nagi's absences. "She's skipped two days since the new term started. Wonder if she'll even bother coming tomorrow…"
Classmate describes Nagi's behavior at school. "She might as well not. Even when she does come, she causes trouble the moment she steps through the gates and gets herself sent right back home."
Classmate laughs at Nagi's behavior. "Kya ha ha! Sounds like her!"
Classmate suggests Nagi might be a killer. "So far as killing goes, I hear she actually is."
Classmate asks for details. "How so?"
Classmate suggests Nagi might have had an abortion. "You know, one slip and you miss your period…"
Classmate continues the speculation. "Ah!"
Classmate suggests Nagi gets suspended to hide it. "Then she gets herself suspended before anyone notices and takes care of it…"
Classmate believes the rumor. "I believe it!"
The narrator notes there's no evidence but they keep talking. There was no evidence at all, but that didn't stop them from talking.
Everyone laughs, including the narrator. Everyone was laughing, though, so I laughed with them.

The narrator's thoughts about Nagi. I didn't hate her like they did. Sure, she was trouble. But there was something about the way that she looked at people that was pretty cool; the way she didn't seem to care whether you were older or even a teacher, but just looked straight at you.
Classmate asks about Nagi's parents. "She's got no parents, right?"

Classmate shares information about Nagi's family. "Yeah, like, they live abroad or something? You heard she was the top scorer on the entrance exam, right? But she wasn't the speaker at the entrance ceremony. Know why?"
Classmate asks why Nagi wasn't the speaker. "Why?"
Classmate explains about Nagi's guardian. "Her guardian's name isn't Kirima."
Classmate suggests Nagi is illegitimate. "She's illegitimate?"
Classmate confirms and adds more details. "Yeah. She just gets money and lives by herself in some apartment."
Classmate expresses disbelief. "No way…"

Classmate speculates about what Nagi could do. "So, she can do whatever she wants. Bring a different guy home every day, or like Suema says, 'Start killing.' She could have a mountain of bodies at her place, and no one would ever know."
Classmate asks where the bodies would be. "In the freezer?"
Classmate continues the gruesome speculation. "All frozen up."
Classmate adds more details. "Thaws them out and cooks them!"
Classmate expresses disgust. "Ew, gross!"
Everyone laughs again. Everyone laughed again.
The narrator goes along with them. I went along with them.

Yurihara-san glares at them. We laughed a bit too loud and Yurihara-san, who was sitting nearby, looked up from her study guide and glared at us. She was the best student in the class…and in the running for top of the school. I'd heard she'd taken practice tests at her cram school, and outscored students from the best schools in town three times running. She was also beautiful…and a little stuck up—meaning that she had no friends in our class. Even though she might've felt a little out of our league, she somehow knew that all it took was a cold glance to quiet us down.
Kyoko suggests Nagi might be Boogiepop. "Maybe Nagi is Boogiepop?" Kyoko said.
Classmate disagrees about Boogiepop's appearance. "Ew, no. Boogiepop's a beautiful boy."
The narrator's first encounter with the name Boogiepop. At the time, that was my first encounter with that name, so I felt myself compelled to ask about it.
Classmate is surprised the narrator doesn't know about Boogiepop. "You don't know? But he's a killer!"
The narrator defends herself. "It's not like I know everything."

The narrator's thoughts on the Boogiepop story. They filled me in, but I'm into criminal psychology, and this was just some school horror story. God, it was beyond absurd. They made it out to be less of a serial killer and more like some crazed monster.
The narrator pretends to be alarmed. "Hmm… That's kinda scary." Everyone was watching, so I had to pretend to be alarmed.
Classmate finds Boogiepop attractive. "Kind of a turn-on, huh? Wonder how he kills them?" With that, they all started babbling away, swooning over this fantasy man of theirs.
The narrator gets irritated by their speculation. Did he strangle them? Run them through with a knife? They kept suggesting rather time-consuming methods of killing, and I started to get irritated.
Kyoko asks for the narrator's expert opinion. "Can we get your expert opinion?" Kyoko asked teasingly, suddenly turning to me.
The narrator suggests poison gas. "Sure…poison gas."
Classmates react to the suggestion. "Ew, like Sarin?" They all said at once.

The narrator specifies the type of poison gas. "Nah, hydrocyanic acid gas. It's colorless and invisible, but very poisonous, and it kills you instantly. You can spray it on someone, and it vanishes quickly, leaving no evidence. The body isn't even dirty. Smells like peaches."
Classmates are creeped out by the narrator's knowledge. "Hunh…?" Everyone was staring at me, slightly creeped out.
The narrator realizes she's made a mistake. Oops, I thought. I'd done it again. I knew full well this kind of knowledge wouldn't interest them.

Kimura-kun approaches the group. At this point, the class lady killer, Kimura-kun, came over and said, "What's up?" Everyone replied, "Nothing…" Apparently the Boogiepop stories were being kept secret from the boys.
The narrator feels like the last to know about the rumor. A myth only the girls knew. It seemed I was the last one in class to hear about it. I always am.
The narrator feels depressed and only half-listens. "………" That depressed me a little, so I only half listened to their conversation, nodding when it seemed appropriate.

beat.summary: The narrator reflects on her past experience.
beat.paragraph: The narrator explains her interest in criminal psychology. My interest in criminal and abnormal psychology stems from a personal experience I had.

The narrator describes almost being killed five years ago. Five years ago, in seventh grade, I was almost killed. There was a serial killer hiding in our town, and he killed himself just when the police were about to catch him.

The narrator explains the killer's interest in her. The killer took sexual pleasure in killing, which is freaky enough, but among the notes that he left behind was one with my address and a detailed account of the route that I took to school.
The narrator realizes she would have been the next victim. Had he not killed himself, it turns out that I would've been his next victim.

The police investigation. The police investigated my family to see if they had any connection to the killer, just to be certain. Of course, we'd never even seen him before. My parents tried to keep it a secret from me, but I found out when the police started questioning me directly.
The narrator's reaction to the news. I would be lying if I said it wasn't a shock. But more powerful than the shock was the unreal feeling that it gave me.

The narrator's thoughts on her life being in someone else's hands. My life had been in the hands of someone with no connection to me at all. I just couldn't wrap my head around the idea, which is exactly how I got interested in that sort of thing to begin with.

The narrator never told her friends why. I never told my friends why. I knew they would look at me differently if I did. "The psycho liked her," they would say, which is more than a good enough reason to put me on the bullied list. It was a bit too harsh of a truth to laugh off.

The narrator's different status in the class. But just being interested in that sort of thing was enough to make me different, and the class tends to treat me like Doctor Murder, but it's a far cry from being bullied.

sequence.summary: After lunch, a student claims to see Boogiepop on the roof, and the narrator investigates.

beat.paragraph: The narrator describes going to class after lunch. After lunch, we all went off to our fifth period classrooms.

The narrator's thoughts on her Modern Japanese class. Even though I was in the science program, my next class was Modern Japanese, a subject that automatically got on my nerves. Our school let you choose between science and humanities concentrations in your second year, but even so, we had to complete one course from the other program during our second year. An absurd requirement, if you ask me.

The narrator walks with a friend. A friend from another class who was also forced to take Japanese walked across the covered walkway with me. Usually, there were three of us, but Niitoki-san was at a meeting for the discipline committee today.

The PA announcement about Miyashita Touka. As we walked, the PA came and said, "…Miyashita Touka, second year, class C. Please, return to the infirmary at once. Miyashita Touka, second year, class C…"
The friend wonders where Touka went. "Hunh, wonder where Touka went?" the girl next to me asked. She was in the same class.
Suema asks if Touka was in the infirmary. "She was in the infirmary?"
The friend confirms Touka was sick. "Yeah, she got sick at the start of fourth bell…"
Suema asks if Touka was faking it. "Faking it?"
The friend suggests Touka might be dating. "Mm… She is dating a senior…"
Suema suggests Touka might be skipping for a date. "Skipping out for a date?"
The friend confirms and asks Suema not to tell Niitoki-san. "Maybe. But dating is against the rules, so don't tell Niitoki-san," she said, putting her finger in front of her lips.
Suema promises not to tell. I grimaced back at her. "I would never."
The friend speculates where Touka might be. "They're probably on the roof or something now…" she said, glancing out the window. Suddenly, she let out a piercing shriek.
Suema asks what's wrong. Startled, I asked, "Wh-what?"
The friend points at something outside. "Th-th-th-there!" She pointed out the window, her finger trembling.
Suema asks what she's pointing at. "What?"
The friend claims to see Boogiepop. "Boogiepop! On the roof!"
Suema expresses disbelief. "Eh?" I stuck my head out the window.
Suema sees nothing on the roof. But there was nothing.
Suema tells her friend there's nothing there. "Nothing there."
The friend insists she saw something. "There was! I saw it! It moved away!"
Suema asks if it might have been someone else. "You sure it wasn't somebody else? Miyashita-san?"
The friend describes what she saw. "I don't think so! It had a black hat on! Like a pipe!" she said, still in a panic.

Suema decides to pretend to believe her friend. Clearly, she was seeing things, but nobody believes that when it happens to them. Reverse psychology was more effective. If I pretended to believe her, she would start listening to me.
Suema offers to check the roof. "Okay. Let's go see," I said, and she spun to stare at me in horror.
The friend is shocked by Suema's suggestion. "Hunh?"
Suema explains why she wants to see Boogiepop. "If Boogiepop is real, then I want to see him."
The friend warns Suema not to go. "No! Don't! It's dangerous!"
Suema reassures her friend and tells her to go to class. "Don't worry. Go ahead, I'll meet you in class."
Suema heads for the roof. I headed for the roof. I ran up almost all of the stairs, and I was pretty out of breath by the time that I reached the door.
The roof door is locked. But the door to the roof was locked. Oh, right; they had belatedly sealed it off after someone had thrown themself off.
Suema looks out the window at the roof. I peered out the window. I could see most of the roof, but there was nobody there.
Suema's friend is waiting for her. When I got down the stairs, she was waiting for me, looking worried.
The friend asks what happened. "Wha-what happened?"
Suema tells her friend there was nothing there. "Nothing there."
The friend asks for confirmation. "Really?"
Suema confirms she looked everywhere. "Yep. I looked everywhere."
The friend concludes she must have imagined it. "Hunh. I guess I must have imagined it…" she said, relieved.

Suema agrees but feels disappointed. "I guess," I replied, surprised to find myself disappointed. As we headed to class, it occurred to me that there was a fire escape at the back of the roof, and if someone had gone down that, I wouldn't have been able to see them. But it was too late to go check now.
Life returns to normal. Nothing like that happened again, and our peaceful, safe lives dragged on.
